questions.text: What part of the brain is primarily damaged in cases of chorea? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Striatum

 

Chorea is characterized by involuntary, rapid, irregular, and purposeless movements that flow from one body part to another. The primary pathological changes in chorea involve the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen). In Huntington's disease, the most well-known cause of chorea, there is selective degeneration of medium spiny neurons in the striatum, with progressive atrophy of the caudate nucleus and putamen visible on neuroimaging. This striatal degeneration disrupts the normal inhibitory output to the globus pallidus, ultimately leading to disinhibition of the thalamus and excessive movement manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Subthalamus: While the subthalamic nucleus plays an important role in the basal ganglia circuitry and movement control, it is not the primary site of pathology in chorea. Damage to the subthalamic nucleus typically results in hemiballismus, which involves more violent, flinging movements than chorea.

 

Option B. Globus pallidus: The globus pallidus is affected secondarily in chorea due to altered inputs from the diseased striatum. Primary globus pallidus lesions more commonly result in parkinsonian features or dystonia rather than chorea.

 

Option C. Substantia nigra: The substantia nigra is the primary site of degeneration in Parkinson's disease, leading to dopamine deficiency and hypokinetic movement disorders. It is not the primary site of pathology in choretic disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chorea primarily results from pathology in the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen), which disrupts the normal basal ganglia circuitry and leads to disinhibition of thalamic nuclei, resulting in the characteristic random, flowing involuntary movements.

questions.text: In a study based in Delhi from 2012-2022, doctors followed up 100 people who did exercise on a daily basis for a year. Later, they checked who all had developed coronary heart disease among them. This is a type of: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Prospective study

 

This is a prospective or cohort study because:

 

  • The exposure (exercise) was identified first
  • The subjects were followed up over time (10 years from 2012 to 2022)
  • The outcome (coronary heart disease) was measured later
  • The direction of the study is forward in time (from exposure to outcome)
  • The study follows a group of similar individuals (cohort) over time

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Case control study: Incorrect because case control studies are retrospective, starting with the outcome (disease) and looking back at exposures. Here, the study started with exposure and looked forward.

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: Incorrect because cross sectional studies measure exposure and outcome at the same point in time. This study involved follow-up over 10 years.

 

Option D. Ecological study: Incorrect because ecological studies analyze population-level data rather than individual data. This study followed individual subjects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A study that starts with exposure, follows subjects over time, and measures outcomes later is a prospective/cohort study.

choices.text: Network analysis and machinery installed
Equipment ordered and staff training
Work sampling and machinery installed

questions.text: Study the management technique given in the diagram. Identify the technique and find out the critical path. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Network analysis and machinery installed

 

The diagram shows a network analysis technique that includes PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method). When analyzing the two possible paths:

 

  • Path 1: 4 + 2 + 1 + 1 = 8 months total duration
  • Path 2: 2 + 10 + 1 = 13 months total duration The critical path is the longer duration path (13 months), where equipment installation takes the longest time (10 months), making it the most critical component.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Equipment ordered and staff training: Incorrect as these are components but not the critical path which has the longest duration 

 

Option C. Work sampling and machinery installed: Incorrect as this is not a work sampling technique, which is used for observing work activities 

 

Option D. Work sampling and staff training: Incorrect as the diagram shows network analysis, not work sampling

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Network analysis consists of two components:

 

  • PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) - Shows sequence of activities

 

 

CPM (Critical Path Method) - Identifies the longest duration path in the network

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hypothermia

 

Osborn waves, also known as J-waves, are characteristic findings on an ECG that are typically associated with hypothermia. These waves appear as a positive deflection at the J point (the junction between the end of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST segment) and are most evident in moderate to severe cases of hypothermia. The appearance of Osborn waves is thought to be caused by a disparity in the action potential durations between the epicardial and endocardial surfaces of the heart during ventricular repolarization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism: This condition does not typically cause Osborn waves. Instead, hypothyroidism can lead to other ECG changes such as bradycardia, low voltage, and possibly prolonged QT interval.

 

Option C. Hypocalcemia: This typically leads to a prolonged QT interval but does not cause Osborn waves.

 

Option D. Hypokalemia: While hypokalemia can cause significant ECG changes, including U waves, flattened T waves, and ST depression, it is not associated with Osborn waves.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

J-wave or Osborn wave is seen in cases of moderate or severe hypothermia due to increase in the epicardial potassium current relative to that of endocardium during ventricular repolarization.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kartagener syndrome

 

 

Kartagener syndrome, also known as primary ciliary dyskinesia with situs inversus, is a genetic disorder characterized by a triad of symptoms: bronchiectasis, chronic sinusitis, and situs inversus. The provided image shows clear evidence of situs inversus (with the heart apex and stomach bubble on the right side) and bronchiectasis (dilated bronchi seen on the X-ray). These findings align perfectly with Kartagener syndrome.

 

In this image:

 

  • The heart apex is seen on the right side, confirming dextrocardia.
  • The stomach bubble is also on the right side, indicating situs inversus.
  • There are multifocal dilated bronchi, which are signs of bronchiectasis.

 

These findings together strongly suggest Kartagener syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labelling error: While it is crucial to confirm that the X-ray is correctly labeled (i.e., left and right markers), in this case, the labeling is correct, and the findings of situs inversus, dextrocardia, and bronchiectasis are genuine.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition refers to the presence of air in the peritoneal cavity, which would not present as dextrocardia or bronchiectasis. It is not consistent with the X-ray findings shown.

 

Option D. Cystic fibrosis: Cystic fibrosis can also present with bronchiectasis, but it does not typically involve situs inversus or dextrocardia, making this an incorrect option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kartagener syndrome is diagnosed based on the triad of situs inversus, bronchiectasis, and chronic sinusitis, often identified by observing the positions of the heart, stomach bubble, and bronchi on imaging.

questions.text: A 58-year-old hypertensive patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI) presents with an acute attack of migraine. Which of the following medications should not be given for migraine in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sumatriptan

 

Sumatriptan belongs to a class of drugs called triptans, which are commonly used to treat migraines. Triptans work by constricting blood vessels in the brain, which helps to relieve migraine pain. However, they can also cause vasoconstriction in other parts of the body, including the coronary arteries. This vasoconstriction can potentially trigger coronary artery spasm, reducing blood flow to the heart and worsening the condition of a patient with a history of myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Sumatriptan and ergotamine are commonly used in treating migraine attacks by stimulating 5HT1B1D receptors, which induce vasoconstriction in the brain to alleviate migraine symptoms. While this vasoconstriction is beneficial within the brain, it can have harmful effects elsewhere. Both drugs can cause vasoconstriction in peripheral blood vessels and the coronary artery, potentially leading to serious conditions:

 

  • Peripheral Vasoconstriction: Could result in gangrene, with ergotamine having a higher risk than sumatriptan.
  • Coronary Artery Spasm: This can exacerbate conditions like myocardial infarction (MI).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ibuprofen: Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) that can be used to manage mild to moderate migraine pain. It does not cause vasoconstriction and is generally safe for patients with a history of MI.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that can be used for migraine prophylaxis (prevention). It does not cause vasoconstriction and can even be beneficial in patients with hypertension, which is a risk factor for both migraine and MI.

 

Option D. Verapamil: Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that can also be used for migraine prophylaxis. It has vasodilatory effects and does not pose a risk of coronary artery spasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Triptans, such as sumatriptan & ergotamine, are contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction or other significant cardiovascular diseases due to their potential to cause coronary artery vasoconstriction

choices.text: Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the α -globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the β-globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the α-globin chain

questions.text: Which Mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene (HBB) located on chromosome 11. This mutation results in the substitution of glutamic acid with valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain. The replacement of glutamic acid with a valine causes polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS), leading to red blood cell sickling, increased rigidity, and vaso-occlusive crises. The sickled cells have reduced deformability and tend to aggregate, causing vascular obstruction, hemolysis, and ischemia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the α -globin chain: Incorrect. The mutation in sickle cell anemia affects the β-globin chain, not the α-globin chain. Additionally, while the amino acid substitution involves valine, it occurs at a specific position in the beta chain.

 

Option B. Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the β-globin chain: Incorrect. While the position (6th) and initial amino acid (glutamic acid) are correct, the substituting amino acid is valine, not leucine. When lysine replaces glutamic acid, it results in hemoglobin C disease.

 

Option D. Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the α-globin chain: Incorrect. This combines two errors - wrong chain (α instead of β) and wrong substituting amino acid (leucine instead of valine).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation resulting in substitution of glutamic acid by valine specifically at position 6 of the β-globin chain.

 

This results in polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS), sickling of red blood cells, and complications such as vaso-occlusive crises and hemolysis.

 

 

COMPLICATIONS:

 

  • Vaso-occlusive crisis: most common clinical complication
  • Aplastic crisis: BM overactivity due to compensatory mechanism → parvovirus infection
  • Sequestration crisis: ↑↑↑splenic size leading to hypovolemia
  • Hemolytic crisis- due to infection, splenic macrophage becomes overactive

questions.text: A child is presented with multiple times loose stools. He is managed with ORS. Glucose in ORS is absorbed via which transporter in GIT?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SGLT-1

 

Sodium-Glucose Transporter 1

 

  • SGLT-1 is a transporter protein located in the small intestine. It plays a crucial role in the absorption of glucose and sodium from the gut lumen into the enterocytes (intestinal cells). In the context of ORS, SGLT-1 facilitates the absorption of glucose, which helps in the rehydration process by increasing fluid absorption.

 

Glucose and galactose are absorbed from intestinal lumen into intestinal cell via secondary active transport using sodium dependent glucose transporter (SGLT-1). On the other hand, the glucose from the intestine cell in to blood at basolateral membrane is transported via passive transporter GLUT-2 (see fig)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT-2 (Sodium-Glucose Transporter 2): SGLT-2 is primarily found in the proximal renal tubules of the kidney and is responsible for the reabsorption of glucose from the urine. It is not involved in the absorption of glucose from the gastrointestinal tract.

 

Option C. GLUT-4 (Glucose Transporter 4): GLUT-4 is a glucose transporter primarily found in muscle and adipose tissue. It is responsible for insulin-mediated glucose uptake into these tissues and is not related to glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Option D. GLUT-2 (Glucose Transporter 2): GLUT-2 is a glucose transporter found in the liver, pancreatic beta cells, and the basolateral membrane of enterocytes. It is involved in glucose uptake by the liver and pancreas and is not the primary transporter for glucose absorption in the gut.

 

Educational Objective:

 

SGLT-1 is the key transporter responsible for the absorption of glucose in the gastrointestinal tract. This mechanism is crucial in the management of conditions like diarrhea, where ORS containing glucose can help rehydrate the body by enhancing fluid absorption.

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 538

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient, on treatment for infertility, came with 6 weeks of amenorrhea, abdominal pain, and mild vaginal bleeding. Her beta hCG level was 2800 mlU/mL. On ultrasound, a 3cm mass was seen in the left adnexa. It contained a gestational sac with no fetal cardiac activity. What is the most appropriate management for this patient hCG- Human chorionic gonadotropin? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Single dose methotrexate

 

Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy can include expectant, medical, or surgical approaches depending on the patient's condition and specific characteristics of the ectopic pregnancy.

 

Medical Management (Single Dose Methotrexate):

 

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist that inhibits DNA synthesis, effectively treating ectopic pregnancies by stopping the growth of the trophoblastic tissue.
  • Indications for Methotrexate:
    • Patient hemodynamically stable.
    • No significant symptoms.
    • Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm.
    • No visible cardiac activity.
    • Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L.
    • No contraindication to Methotrexate.

 

In this scenario, the patient has a beta hCG level of 2800 mIU/mL, a 3 cm mass in the left adnexa, and no fetal cardiac activity, making her an appropriate candidate for single-dose methotrexate therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Expectant management:

 

  • Indications:
    • Clinically stable with no pain.
    • Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L.
    • Tubal ectopic < 35 mm with no visible heartbeat.
    • Ability to return for follow-up.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's beta hCG level is 2800 mIU/mL and she presents with symptoms, thus expectant management is not suitable.

 

Option C. Salpingectomy:

 

  • Indications:
    • Significant pain.
    • Adnexal mass of 35 mm or larger.
    • Visible fetal heartbeat on ultrasound.
    • Serum hCG level of 5000 IU/L or more.
  • Reason for not choosing: The patient's ectopic pregnancy size and beta hCG levels do not meet the criteria for surgical intervention. She is hemodynamically stable and a good candidate for medical management.

 

Option D. Milking of the tube:

 

  • Indications: Generally not a recommended procedure due to the risk of incomplete removal of trophoblastic tissue and subsequent complications.
  • Reason for not choosing: This option is outdated and not typically recommended for the management of ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable patient with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, beta hCG levels < 5000 IU/L, gestational sac size < 3.5 cm, and no fetal cardiac activity, single-dose methotrexate is the most appropriate management option.

 

Ref: Page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

questions.text: Which of the following is earliest to rise in myocardial infarction? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ischemia modified albumin

 

Explanation:

 

In the event of a myocardial infarction, certain biomarkers are released into the bloodstream as a result of cardiac muscle injury.

 

Among the three early markers of myocardial injury, three are particularly significant: myoglobin, heart-type fatty acid binding protein (HFABP), and ischemia modified albumin (IMA). Of these three, ischemia modified albumin is the earliest to rise and also the earliest to fall in response to myocardial ischemia. This rapid change makes it a valuable early diagnostic marker for detecting myocardial infarction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Troponin: Troponins are highly specific markers for myocardial injury and are considered the gold standard for diagnosing myocardial infarction. However, they do not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. Typically, troponin levels start to rise 4-6 hours after the onset of myocardial infarction.

 

Option C. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): LDH is an enzyme found in almost all body tissues and is not specific to cardiac tissue. It is a later marker of myocardial infarction, usually rising within 24-48 hours after the onset of symptoms.

 

Option D. CK MB (Creatine Kinase-MB): CK-MB is a specific isoenzyme found in heart muscle and is used as a marker for myocardial infarction. However, it does not rise as early as ischemia modified albumin. CK-MB levels typically start to increase 3-6 hours after myocardial infarction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ischemia modified albumin is the earliest biomarker to rise in the event of a myocardial infarction, making it a crucial early indicator for diagnosis.

choices.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable
Point C to D is due to opening of Na+ and closure of K+ channels
Point B to D is refractory period

questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Point B to D is refractory period

 

Explanation:

 

The correct statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is point B to D is the refractory period.

 

 

AT POINT 1 - Resting membrane potential: membrane is more permeable to K+ than Na+ at rest. Voltage-gated Na+ and K+ channels are closed.

 

AT POINT 2 - Membrane depolarization: Na+ activation gate opens à Na+ flows inward.

 

AT POINT 3 - Membrane repolarization: Na+ inactivation gate closes at peak potential, thus stopping Na+ inflow. K+ activation gate opens → K+ flows outward.

 

AT POINT 4 - Membrane hyperpolarization: K+ activation gates are slow to close → excess K+ efflux and brief period of hyperpolarization. Voltage-gated Na+ channels switch back to resting state. Na+/K+ pump restores ions concentration.

 

Point 2 to 4 is a part of the refractory period. During this period, the application of even a stronger stimulus will not elicit an action potential.

 

The refractory period is divided into two, an absolute refractory period and a relative refractory period. During the absolute refractory period, the nerve will not be excited no matter how strong a stimulus is given. However, during the relative refractory period, stronger than normal stimuli can cause excitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect. Threshold potential is reached just before point B where a rapid depolarization phase begins.

 

Option B: Incorrect. At point E, the nerve is not more excitable; rather, it is in a hyperpolarized state where more than the normal stimulus would be needed to generate another action potential.

 

Option C: Incorrect. The transition from C to D is characterized by the closing of Na+ channels and the opening of K+ channels, not the other way around.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The phases of an action potential -

 

  • Point A: Represents the resting membrane potential.
  • Point B: Marks the threshold potential.

 

Point C: Represents the peak of the action potential.

 

  • Point D: Repolarization phase
  • Point E: Hyperpolarization phase
  • Absolute refractory period includes points B to around point C
  • Relative refractory period from around point C to D

questions.text: Which of the following is not a radiological finding in a patient with left heart failure? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Focal oligemia

 

Focal oligemia, also known as the Westermark sign, is a radiological finding indicative of pulmonary embolism, not heart failure. It represents a regional reduction in lung vascularity and is seen on chest radiographs as an area of decreased blood flow and enhanced clarity due to vascular obstruction from a clot.

 

Other Options:

 

Radiological Findings in Left Heart Failure:

 

Option A. Kerley B lines: These are thin linear opacities caused by interstitial edema, especially near the lung bases, and are commonly associated with congestive heart failure.

 

Option C. Increased venous blood in lung: Also known as pulmonary venous hypertension, this finding is due to increased pressure in the pulmonary veins that results from left heart failure.

 

Option D. Change in upper lobe circulation: This refers to the redistribution of blood flow to the upper lobes, a classic sign of pulmonary venous hypertension seen in left heart failure.

 

Further Stages of Left Heart Failure on CXR:

 

  1. Stage 1 (PCWP 13-18 mmHg): Cardiomegaly, redistribution of pulmonary vessels, broad vascular pedicle.
  2. Stage 2 (PCWP 18-25 mmHg): Kerley B lines and peribronchial cuffing indicating interstitial edema.
  3. Stage 3 (PCWP > 25 mmHg): Alveolar edema leading to consolidation and pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:


In patients with suspected heart failure, radiological findings such as Kerley B lines, increased pulmonary venous pressure, and altered upper lobe circulation are indicative. Focal oligemia, however, suggests a differential diagnosis of pulmonary embolism and should prompt further investigation for this condition rather than heart failure.

 

 

Reference - Radiology assistant/ CXR in heart failure

questions.text: A female patient presents to you with a unilateral headache. It is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia. What is the best drug for acute management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sumatriptan

 

The patient’s symptoms of unilateral headache accompanied by nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia are classic indicators of a migraine. Migraine is a common condition in young females and can be associated with other symptoms such as primary Raynaud's phenomenon.

 

For the acute management of migraines:

 

  • Mild to moderate attacks – Paracetamol or NSAIDs like Ketorolac.
  • Moderate to severe attacks - Triptans are the drugs of choice. Other group of drugs are Ditans/ Gepants
    • Sumatriptan, Rizatriptan a commonly used triptan, is a 5HT 1B/1D agonist which effectively alleviates migraine symptoms by causing vasoconstriction of the dilated blood vessels thought to be responsible for migraine pain. This action helps to reduce the headache and associated symptoms rapidly. - All of these drugs are contraindicated in the setting of pregnancy except paracetamol. Triptans are unsafe in vascular conditions
    • Ditans (Ex. Lasmiditan) are 5-HT1F receptor agonists. Unlike triptans, they do not cause vasoconstriction, making them safer for patients with vascular conditions such as coronary artery disease or peripheral arterial disease.
    • Gepents are CGRP (calcitonin gene-related peptide) antagonists or blocker. Gepents, including rimegepant, atogepant, ubrogepant, and zabigipant, are effective in migraine management. These are oral medications and do not cause vasoconstriction, which also makes them suitable for patients with certain vascular conditions.

 

Note - Dopamine Receptor Blockers: Prochlorperazine is mentioned as an example of this class. While not the focus of the discussion, dopamine receptor blockers are noted as effective in managing migraines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flunarizine: Flunarizine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily for the prophylactic (preventive) treatment of migraines, not for acute management. It helps in reducing the frequency of migraine attacks but does not relieve symptoms once an attack has started.

 

Option C. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used for the prophylaxis of migraines. It is effective in reducing the frequency and severity of migraine attacks over time but is not used for immediate relief during an acute migraine episode.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Topiramate is an anticonvulsant medication also used for the prophylactic treatment of migraines. Similar to propranolol, it helps prevent migraines but is not effective in treating acute migraine symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sumatriptan is the drug of choice for the acute management of moderate to severe migraine attacks due to its vasoconstrictive properties and effectiveness in rapidly alleviating migraine symptoms.

questions.text: Research is being conducted to find the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer in workers who have worked in the industry for >20 years. Two groups were formed: one directly involved with dye handling and the other group consisting of office clerks not directly exposed to the dye. Years of occupation were noted from records. Then Bladder cancer cases were identified from both the groups in the current time. What type of study is being performed? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Retrospective cohort study

 

The study given here is a retrospective cohort study.

 

A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before commencing the investigations and study.

 

The given question tells that the workers in the industry were divided into two groups, first are those who are directly exposed and second are clerical staff who are not directly exposed to the suspected carcinogen.

 

The incidence of bladder cancer among these two groups is studied going backward tracking their records. Therefore, it’s a retrospective cohort study.

 

A simple comparison between these studies and an example is shown below:
 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prospective cohort study: Involves following a group over a time span till the development of outcome.

 

Option C. Case-control study: A case-control study involves comparing groups with a specific outcome (cases) with a rather healthy group (controls) and assessing their exposure history. In this case, workers are divided into groups based on their exposure status and the development of bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Intervention and response: Is not a type of epidemiological study design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A retrospective cohort study involves examining historical data to investigate the relationship between exposure and outcomes. In this scenario, it is used to study the association between aniline dye exposure and bladder cancer among workers over a 20-year period.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Buccopharyngeal fascia

 

Explanation:


 The marked structure is buccopharyngeal fascia based on its anatomical position:

 

  • Located behind the muscular layer of pharynx
  • Forms outer covering of pharyngeal muscles
  • Lies anterior to retropharyngeal space
  • Follows the arrangement of pharyngeal wall layers from inside out: 
    1. Pharyngobasilar fascia (innermost)
    2. Muscular layer (longitudinal and circular)
    3. Buccopharyngeal fascia
    4. Retropharyngeal space
    5. Alar fascia
    6. Alar space
    7. Prevertebral fascia
    8. Prevertebral space
    9. Vertebra

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Pharyngobasilar fascia

 

  • Forms innermost layer lining pharyngeal cavity
  • Located beneath mucosa
  • Forms tonsillar capsule posteriorly

 

Option C. Alar fascia

 

  • Located posterior to retropharyngeal space
  • Forms anterior boundary of danger space
  • Extends to T4 vertebral level

 

Option D. Prevertebral fascia

 

  • Located most posteriorly before vertebral column
  • Forms posterior boundary of danger space
  • Extends to coccyx

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: All of the following organisms are encapsulated except: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Histoplasma capsulatum

 

Explanation:

 

Histoplasma capsulatum is not an encapsulated organism despite its name suggesting otherwise. The term "capsulatum" in its name is misleading as this fungus does not produce a true capsule.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumoniae - This is a capsulated bacterium with a well-defined polysaccharide capsule. The capsule is a major virulence factor for pneumococci and is the basis for serotyping. The capsule helps the organism resist phagocytosis.

 

Option B. Neisseria meningitidis - Meningococci possess a polysaccharide capsule that is essential for their virulence. The capsule protects the organism from phagocytosis and complement-mediated killing. It's also used for serological classification.

 

Option D. Cryptococcus neoformans - This fungus has a prominent polysaccharide capsule that is a major virulence factor. The capsule can be visualized by India ink preparation, appearing as a clear halo around the yeast cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial and fungal capsules are important virulence factors that primarily function to inhibit phagocytosis, allowing pathogens to evade host immune responses. Despite its name, Histoplasma capsulatum lacks a true capsule, unlike the other organisms listed which all possess well-defined capsular structures.

choices.text: Descending paralysis is seen
Plasmapheresis is a treatment method

questions.text: All are true about Typical Guillain-Barre syndrome except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Descending paralysis is seen

 

Guillain-Barre Syndrome (GBS) is typically characterized by ascending paralysis, starting from the lower extremities and moving upward, not descending paralysis. This pattern begins with weakness in the legs that spreads to the upper limbs and the face, associated with the demyelination of peripheral nerves. The condition is indeed inflammatory and primarily affects the peripheral nervous system, leading to demyelination and sometimes axonal damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammatory condition: True, GBS is an acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy.

 

Option C. Plasmapheresis is a treatment method: True, plasmapheresis is used to remove antibodies from the blood that are thought to be involved in the immune attack on the peripheral nerves.

 

Option D. Demyelinating disorder: True, GBS involves the demyelination of peripheral nerves, leading to muscle weakness and paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GBS produces neuro-radiculopathy due to demyelination causing ascending paralysis.

 

Causes of Descending paralysis (Mnemonic: Bipolar disorder [BPD]):

 

B: Botulism

P: Porphyria, Polio

D: Diphtheria

questions.text: Which toxin can cause acute liver failure and hematuria? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amanita phylloides

 

Explanation:

 

Amanita phylloides, also known as the "death cap" mushroom, contains toxins that can cause both acute liver failure and hematuria. The mushroom contains amatoxins, which are responsible for the severe liver damage, and can also affect the kidneys, leading to renal damage and hematuria. This combination of liver and kidney damage is a characteristic feature of Amanita phylloides poisoning.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option. A. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid that can cause respiratory depression and constipation, but it is not typically associated with acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

Option. B. Ketamine: Ketamine is an anesthetic that can cause dissociative effects and hallucinations, but it is not known to cause acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

Option. C. Belladonna: Atropa Belladonna, also known as deadly nightshade, contains anticholinergic compounds that can cause symptoms such as dry mouth, blurred vision, and tachycardia. However, it is not associated with acute liver failure and hematuria.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amanita phylloides, or the "death cap" mushroom, is a toxin that can cause both acute liver failure and hematuria due to the presence of amatoxins. This combination of liver and kidney damage is a characteristic feature of Amanita phylloides poisoning

questions.text: A middle aged man from West Bengal presents with paraesthesia of hands and feet, hyperkeratosis, lines in the nails and rain drop pigmentation in the hands. The most likely causative toxin for the above mentioned symptoms is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

The symptoms mentioned in the question are classic features of chronic arsenic poisoning.

 

Chronic Arsenic poisoning: It is insidious in nature. The onset of symptoms usually  occurs  after 2–8  weeks of exposure.  Chronic  poisoning  may  occur among persons engaged in smelting and refining of ores and in the subliming of arsenic in the manufacture of weed killers, dyes etc.

 

Clinical Features of Chronic Arsenic poisoning:

 

  1. GIT symptoms: loss of weight, malaise, loss of appetite, salivation, colicky pain, diarrhoea and vomiting.
  2. Liver: Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
  3. Skin symptoms: usually begin with a persistent erythematous flush leading to hyperkeratotic skin and desquamation. Hyperkeratosis is most prominent in the distal parts of the body. Pigmentation is patchy (‘raindrops pigmentation). Skin cancer (Squamous cell carcinoma and basal cell carcinoma) also occurs.
  4. Nails: Aldrich Mees lines (transverse  white  striae  of  the fingernails) may also be seen.
  5. Hairs: Alopecia occurs
  6. Hematological: Anemia, leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow hypoplasia are  seen.  Anemia is normocytic and normochromic
  7.  Peripheral neuropathy: Sensory  and  motor  polyneuritis (sensory  symptoms  usually  predominate)  manifesting  as numbness and tingling in a ‘stocking glove’ distribution.
  8. Blackfoot disease: Due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries.
  9. Encephalopathy
  10. Nephritis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lead: Symptoms Abdominal pain, anemia, neurological deficits, but not specifically hyperkeratosis, Mees lines, or raindrop pigmentation.

 

Option C. Thallium: Symptoms Gastrointestinal disturbances, alopecia, peripheral neuropathy, but lacks the specific skin changes and nail lines associated with arsenic.

 

Option D. Mercury: Symptoms: Tremors, memory loss, gingivitis, and neurological symptoms, but does not cause hyperkeratosis or Mees lines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic arsenic poisoning presents with distinctive symptoms such as paraesthesia, hyperkeratosis, Aldrich Mees lines, and raindrop pigmentation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male came with complaints of asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions and hair loss as given below. What is the most likely causative organism? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Treponema pallidum

 

The patient presents with several key clinical features: asymptomatic generalized papulosquamous rash on the trunk, moist flat grey perianal lesions (condyloma lata), and patchy hair loss. The patchy hair loss, described as "moth-eaten alopecia," is a characteristic feature of secondary syphilis. These signs are strongly indicative of an infection caused by Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for syphilis. The presence of condyloma lata and the specific type of alopecia observed are classical clues pointing towards this diagnosis.

 

DD of Patchy Alopecia – Alopecia areata, Tinea capitis, Trichotillomania, and Secondary Syphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malassezia furfur: This organism is associated with conditions like pityriasis versicolor and seborrheic dermatitis, neither of which typically present with the described combination of symptoms, particularly the moth-eaten alopecia and condyloma lata.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus: While Staphylococcus aureus can cause skin infections and folliculitis, it does not typically cause the type of patchy alopecia or the other systemic symptoms described in this case.

 

Option D. Microsporum canis: This is a dermatophyte that causes tinea capitis, which can lead to patchy hair loss. However, tinea capitis would be associated with scaly patches and other signs of fungal infection rather than the systemic features like condyloma lata seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "moth-eaten alopecia" is a key diagnostic feature of secondary syphilis, and Treponema pallidum is the causative organism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient came with complaints of sudden onset ocular pain and haemorrhagic discharge accompanied with diminution of vision. He is suspected to have acute haemorrhagic conjunctivitis. What is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Enterovirus 70

 

Acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis is caused by enterovirus 70, a picornavirus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterovirus 68: Known to cause respiratory illnesses and has been associated with acute flaccid myelitis, but not typically with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Option B. Enterovirus 69: Less commonly associated with conjunctivitis and more related to respiratory infections.

 

Option D. Enterovirus 71: Known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease and severe neurological diseases, but not typically associated with hemorrhagic conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Enterovirus 70 is the primary causative organism of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, characterized by sudden onset of ocular pain, redness, and hemorrhagic discharge. The condition is highly contagious and typically self-limiting, with supportive care being the mainstay of treatment.

choices.text: Telomere stability is associated with aging
Abnormal telomerase activation is associated with aging
Decreased telomere length is associated with aging
Increased telomere length is associated with aging

questions.text: Choose the correct statement regarding the telomerase theory of aging? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Decreased telomere length is associated with aging.

 

  • Telomeres are short, TG-rich repeated DNA sequences found at the ends of linear eukaryotic chromosomes. Telomeres do not contain any protein coding sequences. They are necessary for the complete replication of chromosome ends as well as the protection of the ends from fusion and degradation.
  • Telomeres at the ends of chromosomes are normally shortened with each cell division. Cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis may result if telomeres are shortened beyond a certain point. This is referred to as replicative senescence.
  • Telomerase is an enzyme that prevents telomeres from shortening. It is a specialized RNA-protein complex that adds nucleotides to the ends of chromosomes by using its own RNA as a template.
  • This enzyme is found in germ cells but not in most somatic cells. As a result, the majority of somatic cells age, their telomeres shorten, and they exit the cell cycle, rendering them unable to generate new cells to replace damaged cells.
  • In somatic cells, abnormal telomerase reactivation causes senescence and apoptosis. It allows the cells to divide more than usual.
  • Telomerase is usually reactivated in stem cells and cancer cells, and telomere length is stabilized, allowing the cells to proliferate indefinitely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Decreased telomere length is associated with aging. Telomeres shorten with each cell division, leading to cell-cycle arrest or apoptosis when they become critically short, contributing to the aging process. Telomerase helps prevent this shortening but is typically inactive in most somatic cells, leading to aging and limited cell division capability.

questions.text: Which of the following is an abnormal cardiovascular system examination finding during pregnancy? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diastolic murmur

 

During pregnancy, several cardiovascular changes occur as normal physiological adaptations. However, a diastolic murmur is never considered normal and always requires further evaluation. Any diastolic murmur detected during pregnancy needs thorough investigation as it may indicate underlying cardiac pathology.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Soft systolic murmur: Incorrect because systolic murmurs are commonly heard during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and cardiac output. They are considered a normal physiological finding.

 

Option C. S3 (Third heart sound): Incorrect because S3 can be heard as a normal finding during pregnancy due to increased blood volume and ventricular filling.

 

Option D. Loud S1 (First heart sound): Incorrect because a loud S1 is a normal cardiovascular finding during pregnancy due to changes in cardiac position and increased blood flow.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While systolic murmurs, S3, and loud S1 are normal cardiovascular examination findings in pregnancy, any diastolic murmur is always pathological and requires evaluation.

questions.text: An elderly woman is brought to the OPD with complaints of behavioral change, a history of multiple falls, urinary incontinence, and dementia. What is your diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Normal pressure hydrocephalus

 

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is characterized by the triad of dementia, gait disturbance (typically apraxia or magnetic gait), and urinary incontinence. This condition often involves enlargement of the cerebral ventricles due to cerebrospinal fluid accumulation, which can exert pressure on surrounding brain structures, particularly affecting the frontal lobes responsible for cognitive and urinary control. The clinical presentation aligns well with the symptoms described in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Frontotemporal dementia: This condition often presents with prominent personality changes and language difficulties rather than the classic triad seen in NPH. Falls are less commonly associated with this form of dementia in its early stages.

 

Option C. Parkinson disease: Typically presents with motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. While dementia can occur in later stages, it is not typically accompanied by urinary incontinence and would not explain the early presence of falls as the primary symptom.

 

Option D. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease: Known for rapid progression of neurological symptoms including dementia, myoclonus (sudden muscle spasms), and significant motor dysfunction. It progresses much faster than what is typically seen in NPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NPH is characterized by Dementia, Apraxia/Magnetic gait with urinary incontinence due to frontal lobe dysfunction

 

Reference - Harrison/Dementia/Chap 434

questions.text: Patient experiences softening of the cervix in early pregnancy. This sign is called as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goodell

 

Goodell's sign refers to the softening of the cervix, which is observed during early pregnancy. This sign occurs due to increased vascularization and changes in the connective tissue of the cervix, making it feel softer compared to the non-pregnant state, where the cervix feels firm like the tip of the nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osiander: This is incorrect. Osiander’s sign refers to the palpable pulsation of the uterine arteries felt through the lateral fornices during a vaginal examination in early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Chadwick: This is incorrect. Chadwick's sign, also known as Jacquemier’s sign, is the bluish discoloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix due to increased blood flow during early pregnancy.

 

Option D. Hegar: This is incorrect. Hegar's sign involves the softening of the lower uterine segment, which is palpable during a bimanual examination, allowing the examiner's fingers to approximate between the uterus and the cervix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goodell's sign is the softening of the cervix, observed in early pregnancy due to increased vascularity, which makes the cervix feel soft, like the lips, compared to its usual firm texture

questions.text: During a surgical procedure, a patient's level of consciousness and awareness under anesthesia is most accurately monitored using: (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bispectral Imaging (BIS Monitoring)

 

Bispectral index (BIS) monitoring is specifically designed to assess the depth of anesthesia by analyzing the patient’s electroencephalogram (EEG). It provides a numerical score from 0 to 100, correlating with levels of consciousness:

 

  • 0–40: Deep anesthesia
  • 40–60: Optimal range for surgical anesthesia
  • 60–100: Increasing levels of consciousness

 

Because BIS monitoring directly reflects brain electrical activity, it is considered the most accurate and objective tool for evaluating a patient’s level of awareness during anesthesia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulse Oximetry: Measures oxygen saturation (SpO₂) and heart rate, essential for monitoring oxygenation, but it offers no insight into the depth of anesthesia or consciousness.

 

Option B. Colour Doppler: A diagnostic tool for assessing blood flow in vessels using ultrasound. It plays no role in monitoring anesthesia depth or patient awareness.

 

Option D. End-Tidal CO₂ (Capnography): Monitors the exhaled carbon dioxide to assess ventilation status and confirm airway placement, but it does not assess consciousness or brain activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bispectral index (BIS) monitoring is the gold standard for assessing depth of anesthesia, offering a reliable, real-time measure of brain activity that guides anesthetic dosing and reduces the risk of intraoperative awareness.

choices.text: Caused by mutation in HPRT gene on chromosome 6

questions.text: All of the following statements about Lesch-Nyhan syndrome are true, except: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Caused by mutation in HPRT gene on chromosome 6

 

Explanation: 

 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by a mutation in the HPRT or HGPRT (Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase) gene, which is located on the X chromosome, not on chromosome 6. This X-linked inheritance pattern explains why the condition predominantly affects males. HGPRT is an enzyme involved in the purine salvage pathway, which allows the body to recycle purines rather than synthesizing them de novo. When this enzyme is deficient, PRPP levels increase, resulting in purine overproduction and subsequent hyperuricemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperuricemia: This is correct. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is characterized by hyperuricemia due to increased nitrogenous bases leading to elevated uric acid levels, which can cause gout-like symptoms and uric acid lithiasis.

 

Option B. Self-mutilative behavior: This is correct. Self-mutilation is a characteristic feature of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, resulting from the neurotoxic effects of increased PRPP levels in the brain.

 

Option C. Compulsive aggression: This is correct. The neurological manifestations of the syndrome include compulsive aggressive behaviors, which are part of the spectrum of self-injurious behaviors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Lesch-Nyhan syndrome results from complete deficiency of HGPRT (an enzyme in the purine salvage pathway) located on the X chromosome, causing both elevated uric acid levels (gout) and neurological manifestations including self-mutilation due to neurotoxic PRPP accumulation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male patient, who is a known case of diabetes mellitus since the past 25 years, came for a health checkup. He was found to have uncontrolled blood sugar levels and third cranial nerve palsy. Which is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in such a case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ptosis

 

  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy is caused by hyperglycemia-induced damage to nerve cells and neuronal ischemic change.
  • The arrangement of the fibers in the third cranial nerve is such that the fibers controlling the pupillary reflex are superficial and often spared from diabetic ischemia-induced injury.
  • Pupillary dysfunction is not commonly present in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • The levator palpebrae superiors and most of the oculomotor muscles, except for the lateral rectus and superior oblique, are damaged in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.
  • Diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy typically presents with ptosis and diplopia.

 

APPLIED ANATOMY OF PUPILLOMOTOR NERVE FIBRES

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Proptosis: Protrusion of the eye, not typically associated with diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy.

 

Option B. Pseudoptosis: False appearance of ptosis, not related to actual muscle dysfunction.

 

Option D. Pupillary dysfunction: Although part of the oculomotor nerve's function, it is usually spared in diabetic oculomotor nerve palsy due to the peripheral location of the pupillary fibers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) is the most common feature of third nerve palsy seen in diabetic patients, due to the selective ischemic damage to the central fibers of the oculomotor nerve, sparing the peripheral pupillary fibers.

questions.text: A 54-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with fatigue, tiredness and cervical lymphadenopathy. The TLC and DLC were normal. No immature cells. A lymph node biopsy was performed which shows diffuse effacement of the Lymph node architecture, cells with an indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus, and are atypical. CD10 and BCL2 are positive. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

 

The clinical scenario presented here, which includes fatigue, tiredness, and cervical lymphadenopathy with CD10 positive BCL2 positive cells, strongly suggests follicular lymphoma.

 

The most common type of indolent NHL is follicular lymphoma. It usually appears in middle age and affects both men and women equally. The tumour is most likely caused by germinal centre B cells.

 

A (14;18) translocation between the IgH locus on chromosome 14 and the BCL2 locus on chromosome 18 is the hallmark of follicular lymphoma.

 

Histologically, at low magnification, a predominantly nodular or nodular and diffuse growth pattern is observed in involved lymph nodes. Two principal cell types are present in varying proportions: (1) small cells with irregular or cleaved nuclear contours and scant cytoplasm, referred to as centrocytes (small cleaved cells); and (2) larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm, referred to as centroblasts.

 

Immunophenotyping - The neoplastic cells closely resemble normal germinal center B cells, expressing CD19, CD20, CD10, surface Ig, and BCL6. CD5 is not expressed. BCL2 is expressed in more than 90% of cases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Burkitt Lymphoma: Typically presents with a high-grade lymphoma and a starry sky pattern on histology. It is associated with c-MYC translocation and does not usually express BCL2.

 

Option C. Mycosis Fungoides: A type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma that presents with skin lesions and does not typically show CD10 or BCL2 positivity.

 

Option D. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML): Characterized by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (BCR-ABL fusion gene) and presents with marked leukocytosis and often splenomegaly, not with lymphadenopathy and histological findings as described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Follicular lymphoma is characterized by diffuse effacement of lymph node architecture, cells with indented nuclei and prominent nucleoli, and positive immunophenotyping for CD10 and BCL2. It typically presents in middle-aged individuals with symptoms such as fatigue, tiredness, and lymphadenopathy. The presence of the t(14;18) translocation involving BCL2 is a hallmark of this indolent non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH (Growth Hormone)

 

Growth Hormone (GH) is known to increase during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep. During stress, the body requires more energy, which can be facilitated by the metabolic effects of GH. Similarly, during starvation or hypoglycemia, GH levels rise to help mobilize fat stores and increase blood glucose levels.

 

Deep sleep, particularly the NREM stage 3 (previously referred to as stages 3 and 4), is a crucial time for the release of GH. This hormone plays a significant role in growth, cell repair, and metabolism, which are all essential processes that occur during deep sleep.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ACTH: ACTH (Adrenocorticotropic Hormone) is released in response to stress but not significantly during starvation or deep sleep. Its primary function is to stimulate the production of cortisol from the adrenal glands.

 

Option C. Cortisol: Cortisol is another hormone released in response to stress and can be elevated during periods of starvation. However, it does not increase during deep sleep, making it an incorrect answer for this question.

 

Option D. Prolactin: Prolactin is not associated with increases during stress or starvation. In fact, stress can decrease prolactin levels, particularly in nursing mothers. Prolactin levels do not significantly increase during deep sleep either.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Growth Hormone (GH) increases during periods of stress, starvation, and deep sleep, especially during the NREM stage 3 of sleep.

choices.text: It is an inherited red blood cell disorder causing intravascular hemolysis
The diagnosis of the disorder is confirmed by sucrose lysis test
Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition
The commonest cause of mortality is cardiac failure

questions.text: Which of the following is a true/correct statement about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition


Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is an acquired, not inherited, clonal hematopoietic stem cell disorder that leads to red blood cell destruction (intravascular hemolysis), thrombosis, and bone marrow failure.

 

The gold standard for diagnosing PNH is flow cytometry, which detects the absence of GPI-anchored proteins (CD55 and CD59) on red blood cells, granulocytes, and monocytes.

 

 The absence of these proteins makes cells vulnerable to complement-mediated destruction, characteristic of PNH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is an inherited red blood cell disorder causing intravascular hemolysis: This statement is incorrect because PNH is not inherited but acquired due to a somatic mutation in the PIGA gene in hematopoietic stem cells.

 

Option B. The diagnosis of the disorder is confirmed by sucrose lysis test: The sucrose lysis test is an older screening test for PNH but is not confirmatory. It has largely been replaced by flow cytometry, which is more accurate and specific for detecting the absence of CD55 and CD59.

 

Option D. The commonest cause of mortality is cardiac failure: This statement is incorrect. The most common cause of mortality in PNH is thrombotic complications, especially hepatic vein thrombosis (Budd-Chiari syndrome), not cardiac failure.

 

Educational Objective:


Flow cytometry is the definitive test for diagnosing PNH by demonstrating the absence of CD55 and CD59 on blood cells.

questions.text: In Presence of ADH, Maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid will be in which of the following site of nephron? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Medullary CD

 

Explanation: 

 

ADH increases water permeability in the collecting ducts by inserting aquaporin channels. When ADH is present, as we move from the cortex towards the deep medulla, osmolarity keeps increasing. Though ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum change in osmolarity occurs in the medullary region due to the countercurrent multiplication system maintaining high osmolarity in the medullary interstitium.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCT: Incorrect because PCT mainly handles obligatory water reabsorption (60-70%) through osmosis, not regulated by ADH.

 

Option B. Cortical CD: Incorrect because although ADH acts here, the osmotic gradient in the cortex is much lower than in the medulla.

 

Option C. DCT: Incorrect because DCT has minimal water reabsorption (1-3%) without ADH and is not a major site for ADH action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While ADH acts on both cortical and medullary collecting ducts, the maximum osmolarity of tubular fluid is achieved in the medullary collecting duct due to the high osmotic gradient maintained by the countercurrent multiplication system in the medulla.

questions.text: In a patient, eye blinking occurs when a doctor touches the eye with a piece of cotton. Which of the following nerves is responsible for carrying sensation? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) V CN (Trigeminal Nerve)

 

The ophthalmic division (V1) of trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from:

  • The cornea and conjunctiva
  • The skin of upper eyelid
  • Forehead and upper face
    • When cotton touches the cornea, V1 carries this sensory information to the brain 
    • This triggers the corneal reflex (protective blinking)

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. II CN (Optic Nerve):

 

  • This nerve is purely sensory but specifically for vision
  • It carries visual information from the retina to the brain
  • It does not carry touch/tactile sensation from the surface of the eye

 

Option B. III CN (Oculomotor Nerve):

 

  • This is mainly a motor nerve
  • Controls eye movements and pupil constriction
  • Also controls upper eyelid elevation
  • Does not carry sensory information from the eye surface

 

Option D. VII CN (Facial Nerve):

 

  • This is mainly a motor nerve
  • It controls facial muscle movements including eyelid closure
  • While it participates in the blinking reflex by closing the eye (motor part), it does not carry the initial sensory information
  • It is the "output" part of the reflex, not the "input" sensory part

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) carries sensory information from the face and eye region, while the facial nerve (CN VII) provides motor innervation for facial expressions including blinking.

choices.text: Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb
Water outflow in thin descending limb
Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb
Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

questions.text: All of the following are components responsible for the countercurrent mechanism in the kidney except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Flow of tubular fluid from PCT and DCT

 

Explanation

 

PCT and DCT is not a component of the countercurrent mechanism.

 

Countercurrent system has two divisions:

 

  1. Countercurrent multiplier formed by loop of Henle & Medullary CD
  2. Countercurrent exchanger formed by vasa recta.

 

The major factors that contribute to the buildup of solute concentration into the renal medulla are as follows:

 

  1. Ascending limb of loop of Henle - thick portion (Active transport) and thin portion (Passive transport) of sodium ions and co-transport of potassium, chloride, and other ions into the medullary interstitium
  2. Descending limb of loop of Henle – Passive transport of water from the tubules to interstitium
  3. Inner medullary collecting ducts - facilitated diffusion of large amounts of urea into the medullary interstitium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium outflow in thick ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it is a key component of the countercurrent multiplier, actively transporting sodium out of the tubular fluid.

 

Option B. Water outflow in thin descending limb: Incorrect as exclusion because it contributes to the countercurrent mechanism by allowing water to passively leave the tubular fluid, increasing its concentration.

 

Option C. Sodium outflow in thin ascending limb: Incorrect as exclusion; although less active than the thick segment, it still participates in sodium transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow of tubular fluid from the PCT and DCT is not a component of the kidney's countercurrent mechanism, which primarily involves the loop of Henle and medullary collecting ducts in actively and passively managing solute and water concentrations to concentrate urine.

questions.text: What is the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) class for the patient who has a serum bilirubin 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin 3 g/dL, prothrombin time 5 seconds (INR = 2), no encephalopathy, and mild ascites? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Class B

 

To determine the Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score, each of the five clinical measures is scored with points from 1 to 3 based on specific criteria:

 

  1. Bilirubin:
    • <2 mg/dL = 1 point
    • 2-3 mg/dL = 2 points (Patient has 2.5 mg/dL)
    • 3 mg/dL = 3 points
  2. Albumin:
    • 3.5 g/dL = 1 point
    • 2.8-3.5 g/dL = 2 points
    • <2.8 g/dL = 3 points (Patient has 3 g/dL, scoring 2 points)
  3. INR:
    • 1-1.7 = 1 point
    • 1.8-2.3 = 2 points (Patient has INR = 2)
    • 2.3 = 3 points
  4. Ascites:
    • None = 1 point
    • Controlled = 2 points (Patient has mild ascites, scoring 2 points)
    • Refractory = 3 points
  5. Encephalopathy:
    • None = 1 point (Patient has none)
    • Grade 1-2 = 2 points
    • Grade 3-4 = 3 points

 

Scoring Calculation:

 

  • Bilirubin = 2 points
  • Albumin = 2 points
  • INR = 2 points
  • Ascites = 2 points
  • Encephalopathy = 1 point
    Total = 9 points

The patient scores 9 points, placing them in Child-Turcotte-Pugh Class B.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system

 

 

Inference:

 

  • CTP A: 5-6
  • CTP B: 7-9
  • CTP C: 10-15

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chapter 344

questions.text: Boundaries of Calot triangle are formed by all except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Gall bladder

 

The gallbladder itself does not form a boundary of Calot's triangle. Instead, it's closely related to the triangle, being situated just adjacent to it.

 

It's an important landmark in cholecystectomy (surgical removal of the gallbladder) because of the structures that it contains. The identification of this triangle helps to prevent injury to the common bile duct during surgery.

 

  • Boundaries of Calot's triangle is bounded:
    • Medially/Left side - Common hepatic duct
    • Right side/ Laterally   Cystic duct
    • Superior - lower surface of liver
    • Contents of calot’s triangle - Cystic artery and lymph node of lund 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Common hepatic duct: This forms the inferior boundary of Calot's triangle. The common hepatic duct is the duct formed by the joining of the left and right hepatic ducts. It later joins the cystic duct to form the common bile duct.

 

Option B. Cystic duct: This duct connects the gallbladder to the common hepatic duct and subsequently forms the common bile duct. The cystic duct forms the lateral boundary of Calot's triangle.

 

Option C. Cystic artery: Inferior surface of liver forms the superior boundary of calot’s triangle

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocystic triangle and triangle of Calot - Hepatocystic triangle (blue): Upper boundary of hepatocystic triangle is the inferior border of liver. Lateral, the cystic duct and the neck of the gallbladder. Medial, the common hepatic duct.

questions.text: Maximum brain growth occurs at which year of life? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 years

 

Brain growth reaches its maximum around 2 years of age. This early and rapid growth phase is crucial for the development of cognitive and motor skills, and it aligns with significant milestones in early childhood development, such as language acquisition, sensory processing, and coordination. The early years are critical for brain development, as synaptic connections are formed at a rapid pace during this time.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 6 years: At 6 years of age, the lymphoid tissues reach their maximum size. The lymphoid system includes the tonsils, adenoids, and other components of the immune system, which are prominent in early childhood to protect against infections.

 

Option C. 10 years: This age is not specifically associated with peak growth in any of the major developmental domains mentioned (brain, lymphoid, somatic, or puberty).

 

Option D. 12 years: This age marks the peak growth for somatic (body) growth and the onset of puberty. During this period, there is a significant increase in height and secondary sexual characteristics as the body undergoes maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The maximum brain growth occurs by 2 years of age, emphasizing the importance of early childhood for brain development.

 

Remember:

 

  • Brain Growth max at 2 years
  • Lymphoid Growth max at 6 years
  • Puberty and Somatic Growth max at 12 years

questions.text: Identify the vitamin deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin D

 

Vitamin D The image show Bowing of the legs, a condition known as bowlegs or genu varum, is commonly associated with Vitamin D deficiency, especially in children. Vitamin D plays a crucial role in the regulation of calcium and phosphorus, essential minerals for bone health. Deficiency of Vitamin D can lead to improper mineralization of bones, resulting in deformities such as bowing of the legs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency is not typically associated with bowing of the legs. However, severe vitamin A deficiency cause night blindness and other eye menifestations.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Vitamin B3 deficiency can cause pellagra, which involves skin, gastrointestinal, and neurological symptoms. It is not directly linked to bowing of the legs.

 

Option D. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): Vitamin B1 deficiency can lead to beriberi, a condition that primarily affects the cardiovascular and nervous systems. It is not a common cause of bowing of the legs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D

questions.text: Which of The following muscle relaxants injection causes maximal pain? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rocuronium

 

Rocuronium is known to cause the most intense injection pain among non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers. The pain is often immediate and described as burning or stinging, largely due to its low pH and osmolality, which irritate the vascular endothelium. Pain on injection can occur in 50–80% of patients when no pretreatment is given. To minimize discomfort, lidocaine pretreatment or administration after induction with propofol is commonly practiced.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Succinylcholine: Although succinylcholine may lead to postoperative myalgia, it typically does not cause pain on injection. Because it is administered rapidly after induction, any injection-related discomfort is rarely noticed.

 

Option B. Vecuronium: Vecuronium is virtually painless on injection. With a near-neutral pH, it is well tolerated and often selected when avoiding injection discomfort is important.

 

Option D. Cisatracurium: Cisatracurium causes minimal to no injection pain. It has a more stable pH and a lower propensity for histamine release compared to atracurium, its parent compound.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Rocuronium causes the most injection pain among neuromuscular blockers, and pretreatment is often needed to reduce discomfort.

questions.text: A patient was started on antihypertensive drugs. Few days later, the patient presented with the following picture. Which of the following drugs is the most likely cause? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lisinopril

 

The given picture is suggestive of angioedema. The antihypertensive drug that can lead to the development of angioedema is ACE-Inhibitors – Lisinopril in the given option. Angioedema caused by ACE inhibitors is a class effect, and patients who experience this side effect should not be given any other ACE inhibitors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina. It can cause side effects such as headache, flushing, and peripheral edema, but it is not typically associated with angioedema.

 

Option C. Atenolol: Atenolol is a beta-blocker used to treat hypertension and other cardiovascular conditions. Its common side effects include bradycardia, fatigue, and cold extremities, but it does not cause angioedema.

 

Option D. Clonidine: Clonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension. It can cause side effects such as dry mouth, sedation, and rebound hypertension upon abrupt withdrawal, but it is not associated with angioedema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Side effects of ACE-Inhibitors are:-

 

  • Angioedema
  • Cough
  • Taste disturbances (Dysguesia)
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Hyperkalemia
  • They are contraindicated in Pregnancy and in patients with B/L Renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ABCC2

 

Molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is ABCC2 (codes for canalicular protein with ATP-binding cassette), it leads to the mutation of multiple drug-resistant protein 2 (MRP2) receptor. Hence, there is a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin from the liver to bile in Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A: This gene is associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option B. ATP7B: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, another disorder of copper metabolism.

 

Option D. SERPINA1: This gene is associated with Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, a condition that can lead to liver and lung disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The molecular defect causing liver disease in Dubin-Johnson syndrome is in the ABCC2 gene, which encodes for a canalicular protein involved in the excretion of conjugated bilirubin.

questions.text: Two girls in the same class are diagnosed with meningococcal meningitis. Their 12-year-old friend from the same school is afraid of contracting the disease. What advice should be given to the exposed students? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotic prophylaxis

 

The best advice for the exposed students is to receive antibiotic prophylaxis. This is recommended for close contacts of a person with meningococcal meningitis, such as household members, intimate contacts, and anyone who has had direct contact with the patient's oral secretions. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be initiated as soon as possible after exposure and can be effective in preventing secondary cases of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Two doses of polysaccharide vaccine: While vaccination is important, it takes time to provide protection. Therefore, it is not the best option for immediate protection in this situation.

 

Option C. Two doses of conjugate vaccine: The conjugate vaccine is recommended for adolescents and children, but similar to the polysaccharide vaccine, it does not provide immediate protection. Antibiotic prophylaxis is still necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Option D. Single dose of meningococcal vaccine: Again, vaccination alone is not sufficient for immediate protection, and antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary for those who have been exposed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For immediate protection after exposure to meningococcal meningitis, antibiotic prophylaxis is necessary. Vaccination is also recommended but does not provide immediate protection.

questions.text: Which of the following tonometry techniques utilizes the Imbert-Fick Law Principle? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Applanation Tonometry

 

Applanation tonometry is specifically based on the Imbert-Fick Law (P=F/A), where pressure equals force divided by area. This principle states that the pressure inside an ideal sphere equals the force necessary to flatten its surface divided by the area of flattening. In applanation tonometry, the instrument's footplate flattens the cornea, and the pressure required for this flattening directly correlates with intraocular pressure. Fluorescein dye is used during the procedure, viewed under cobalt blue light to identify when the mires juxtapose each other, indicating the measurement endpoint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Indentation Tonometry: This method, exemplified by the Schiotz tonometer, works on a different principle where a plunger indents the cornea. It depends on the relationship between the depth of corneal indentation and intraocular pressure, and is affected by scleral rigidity. It does not utilize the Imbert-Fick Law.

 

Option C. Dynamic Contour Tonometry: This is a more recent technique using a contoured tip that matches the shape of the cornea to minimize distortion. It uses a pressure sensor to directly measure intraocular pressure rather than applying the Imbert-Fick principle.

 

Option D. Rebound Tonometry: This technique involves propelling a small probe toward the cornea and analyzing its rebound characteristics. The deceleration of the probe upon corneal impact correlates with IOP. It works on principles of motion dynamics rather than the Imbert-Fick Law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Imbert-Fick Law (P=F/A) is the fundamental principle behind applanation tonometry, where the force required to flatten a specific area of cornea directly correlates with intraocular pressure - making it the gold standard for IOP measurement.

questions.text: A patient of sickle cell anemia developed aplastic crisis after a viral infection. The agent causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parvovirus B19

 

Parvovirus B19 is known for its predilection for erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow, which it infects and destroys. This leads to a transient halt in red blood cell production, which can precipitate an aplastic crisis, particularly in patients with underlying hemolytic disorders like sickle cell anemia. The virus effectively shuts down erythropoiesis (red blood cell production), causing a significant drop in hemoglobin levels and resulting in severe anemia.

 

Patients with sickle cell anemia are particularly susceptible to this type of crisis because they already have a high rate of red blood cell turnover due to the intrinsic hemolysis caused by their abnormal hemoglobin. When Parvovirus B19 infection superimposes on this condition, the cessation of red cell production can lead to a profound aplastic crisis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause various infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, but it is not known to specifically cause aplastic crises or target red blood cell production.

 

Option B. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): EBV is associated with infectious mononucleosis and can affect the lymphoid tissue but does not directly cause aplastic crisis by targeting red blood cell production.

 

Option C. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus): HBV primarily affects the liver, causing hepatitis, and does not have a known mechanism of inducing aplastic crisis by directly affecting the bone marrow's red blood cell production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Parvovirus B19 is the primary viral agent responsible for causing aplastic crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia due to its affinity for and destruction of erythroid progenitor cells in the bone marrow.

questions.text: A patient with HIV who is currently on antiretroviral therapy consisting of zidovudine, lamivudine, and nevirapine is diagnosed with tuberculosis. Considering potential drug interactions, which of the following TB drugs should be changed in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rifampicin

 

Rifampicin is a potent enzyme inducer that significantly increases the metabolism of several drugs, including non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NNRTIs) like nevirapine. When used together, rifampicin accelerates the metabolism of nevirapine, reducing its efficacy in treating HIV. This interaction can lead to subtherapeutic levels of nevirapine, thereby compromising the effectiveness of the antiretroviral therapy.

 

In patients with HIV who are on nevirapine-based antiretroviral therapy, rifampicin is usually substituted with rifabutin. Rifabutin has a similar efficacy against tuberculosis but with a lesser degree of enzyme induction, making it a safer option in this context.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Isoniazid is generally safe to use in patients on antiretroviral therapy, as it does not significantly interact with most HIV medications.

 

Option C. Ethambutol: Ethambutol does not have significant interactions with antiretroviral drugs and is safe to use in this patient population.

 

Option D. Streptomycin: Streptomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, also does not interact significantly with antiretroviral therapy and is not the drug that needs to be changed in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For HIV and TB cotreatment:

 

  • If a person is on the TLE regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, efavirenz), it does not interact with rifampicin. The regimen can continue unchanged even if rifampicin is given.
