  • If the person is on the TLD regimen (tenofovir, lamivudine, dolutegravir), the dose of dolutegravir should be doubled when rifampicin is used, while the rest of the regimen remains the same.
  • If the person is taking a protease inhibitor or nevirapine, rifampicin should be avoided. Instead, rifampicin should be replaced with rifabutin.

questions.text: The preferred test for evaluating the difference in means between two study groups, where one group functions as a control, is: [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Unpaired t test

 

When comparing the means of two independent groups, where one group serves as a control, the appropriate statistical test to use is the unpaired t-test. This test is designed to determine if there is a significant difference between the means of the two independent groups.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chi-square test: This test is used for categorical data to assess whether there is a significant association between two variables.

 

Option B. Z test: The Z test is typically used for large sample sizes to compare the means of two populations or to test proportions.

 

Option D. Paired T test: The paired t-test is used when comparing means from the same group at different times or under different conditions (e.g., before and after treatment).

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Failure of closure of neural tube at week 3 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of neural tube at week 4 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of cranial neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life
Failure of closure of caudal neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life

questions.text: The following anomaly occurs due to (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Failure of closure of cranial neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life

 

Explanation:

 

The image depicts a condition known as anencephaly, a severe neural tube defect characterized by the absence of a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp. This condition arises due to the failure of the cranial (anterior) neuropore to close during embryonic development.

 

  1. Neural Tube Development: The neural tube forms from the neural plate, which folds to create the neural groove and eventually closes to form the neural tube. This process begins around the third week of intrauterine life and continues into the fourth week.
  2. Closure of Neuropores: The neural tube has two openings, the cranial (anterior) and caudal (posterior) neuropores. The cranial neuropore normally closes by the 25th day of gestation (around the 4th week), while the caudal neuropore closes by the 28th day (also around the 4th week).
  3. Anencephaly: When the cranial neuropore fails to close, the result is anencephaly. This defect prevents the proper formation of the forebrain, resulting in the absence of major portions of the brain and skull.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Failure of closure of neural tube at week 3 intra-uterine life: This is incorrect because the neural tube begins to close around the third week, but the critical closure of the cranial neuropore occurs in the fourth week.

 

Option B. Failure of closure of neural tube at week 4 intra-uterine life: This is partially correct but not specific. The specific failure involved in anencephaly is the closure of the cranial neuropore, not just any part of the neural tube.

 

Option D. Failure of closure of caudal neuropore at week 4 intra-uterine life: This is incorrect as it refers to the closure of the caudal neuropore, which would lead to defects like spina bifida, not anencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly results from the failure of the cranial (anterior) neuropore to close by the 25th day of gestation, which occurs around the 4th week of intrauterine life.

choices.text: Palm and soles

questions.text: Where are the apocrine glands present among the given options? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Axilla

 

Option C Axilla:

 

  • Apocrine glands are predominantly located in the axillae, areola and groin.
  • They are sweat glands that become active at puberty and are responsible for the body odor associated with sweating because they produce a thicker, milky sweat that, once degraded by skin bacteria, generates a noticeable odor.

 

 

  • These glands are most numerous in the axillary region, which is why the axilla is the correct answer.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Palm and Soles:

 

  • The skin of palms and soles is primarily populated with eccrine sweat glands, not apocrine.
  • Eccrine glands are involved in thermoregulation and are not associated with hair follicles. They produce a watery sweat that is not typically odorous.

 

Option B. Face:

 

  • While there are some apocrine glands on the face, they are not as numerous or as active as those in the axilla.
  • The face primarily contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands.

 

Option D. Scalp:

 

  • The scalp does have apocrine glands, but they are far less concentrated and active compared to those in the axilla.
  • The scalp also contains eccrine sweat glands and is rich in sebaceous glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify the axilla as the primary location of apocrine sweat glands.

 

Ref: Rooks textbook of dermatology 9th edition Page no 2.8

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for a 0.5 cm carcinoid tumor located at the tip of the appendix? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Appendectomy

 

Explanation:

 

For carcinoid tumors of the appendix, the size and location of the tumor are the key determinants for treatment. For tumors less than 2 cm in size that are located at the tip of the appendix, simple appendectomy is considered adequate treatment. Carcinoid tumors of the appendix rarely metastasize, especially when small and distally located. The 0.5 cm tumor described in the question is well below the size threshold that would warrant more extensive surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Right Hemicolectomy - This more extensive procedure is indicated only when: (1) the tumor is 2 cm or larger in size, (2) the base of the appendix or cecal wall is involved, or (3) there is evidence of lymph node metastasis. None of these conditions are present for a 0.5 cm tumor at the tip.

 

Option C. Omentectomy - This procedure involves removal of the omentum and is not indicated for appendiceal carcinoid tumors unless there is evidence of peritoneal spread, which is extremely rare for small carcinoids.

 

Option D. Hepatic wedge resection - This would only be considered if there were liver metastases, which are exceptionally rare with small appendiceal carcinoid tumors, especially those <1 cm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Small carcinoid tumors (<2 cm) at the appendiceal tip can be adequately treated with simple appendectomy, as they have minimal metastatic potential and excellent prognosis following this conservative approach.

choices.text: Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation
It is associated with a case of electrical burns

questions.text: Identify the true statement about the image given below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Due to sulphemoglobin accumulation and formation

 

The above image shows postmortem change of marbling.

 

Marbling:

 

  1. Marbling is a characteristic colour change occurring in Putrefaction in which the superficial veins become visible on the skin due to staining by Hemoglobin or sulphmethhaemoglobin
  2. Mechanism of colour change in putrefaction:
    1. Direct staining by Hemoglobin (Hb): Lyses of RBCs occur in putrefaction which releases the Hb. This Hb itself stains the tissues and vessels producing a reddish brown coloration which later becomes greenish black.
    2. Staining by Sulph-meth-haemoglobin: Hydrogen sulphides gas produced by decomposing tissues combine with Hb to form sulph-meth-haemoglobin. This sulph-meth-haemoglobin stains the tissues and vessels producing a greenish black colour.
  3. This greenish black staining of superficial veins appears as prominent lines on the skin called Marbling
  4. Marbling is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of abdomen, shoulders, chest and inguinal region.
  5. Marbling starts in 24 hours and becomes prominent in about 36–48 hours after death in summer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seen within 24 hours of death: While marbling starts within 24 hours, it becomes more prominent at around 36–48 hours.

 

Option C. Due to aseptic nonbacterial cause: Marbling is a result of bacterial activity and the decomposition process, not aseptic causes.

 

Option D. It is associated with a case of electrical burns: Marbling is not associated with electrical burns; it is a postmortem change due to putrefaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marbling, a postmortem change characterized by greenish-black lines on the skin, is due to the accumulation and formation of sulph-meth-hemoglobin during putrefaction.
